title: How long an adversary proceeding can take up to complete (from start to end in no of months)? Which one - Jury or bench trial?
question: In a bankruptcy AP (adversary proceeding), how long it take to complete the process? I know it depends on the facts of the case/allegation but normally does AP have their own set of rules or done like a any other civil litigation and if there is rough estimate, how long it would take in terms of months from start to finish?
question_tags: Bankruptcy,Bankruptcy court,Bankruptcy adversary proceeding,Debt,Bankruptcy and debt,Criminal defense,Fraud,Filing a lawsuit
answers:
AP can take minimum of approximately 9 months up to several years to resolve.
Often settled in much shorter time. Every case unique.
FRCP governs conduct of the action.
Pro's and con's of bench v jury trial depend on information not provided.

An adversary proceeding is like any other federal litigation. Typically takes nine months to a year but could go longer depending on the complexity of the issues. You follow the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure. To attempt this litigation without an experienced bankruptcy litigation attorney is pure folly.

Are you the actual debtor or the attorney for the debtor? If you are the debtor, you are in very deep water, and sinking fast. BK is not a DIY project. Click the Avvo tab "Find a Lawyer" in your area. Some offer a free consultation by phone or in person. Talk with 2-3 then hire one ASAP.
